posts.cooked:
We’re using a navX2-MXP for our gyro. I’m having a problem with the yaw being off. The navX is mounted horizontally on top of the roborio.

I start by resetting the gyro in software, and it correctly reports a yaw of 0. I then rotate the robot either CW or CCW for 3 rotations. The reported yaw is off by approx 15 degrees. If I continue in the same direction the error accumulates. When I then rotate in the opposite direction with the same number of rotations, the yaw correctly goes back to 0.

Anyone have an idea of why this is happening?

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked:
MikeB:

resetting the gyro in software, and it correctly reports a yaw of 0. I then rotate the robot either CW or CCW for 3 rotations. The reported yaw is off by approx 15 degrees. If I continue in the same direction the error accumulates. When I then rotate in the opposite direction with the same number of rotations, the yaw correctly

You absolutely should be getting accuracy than that. Take a look at the factory calibration in the user guide: https://pdocs.kauailabs.com/navx-mxp/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/navx2-mxp_robotics_navigation_sensor_user_guide-8.pdf

posts.name: Max Mayer
posts.cooked:
We had a very similar issue on our reported yaw in 2023 we tried every form of calibration and other possible software fixes (including firmware updates and the scaling factor) we could think of and after a comp. and a half we determined it must be a defect with our navX2, so we asked another team at our comp for an original navX instead of the NavX2 and the drift went from  consistent 10-20 degrees off to maybe 1 or 2 degrees off expected.

Edit: I found the thread that helped us the most, I’d follow the advice of Programming4907.

link_counts.title: navX2-sensor Yaw Angle Accuracy Issue Update

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked:
MikeB:

We’re using a navX2-MXP for our gyro. I’m having a problem with the yaw being off. The navX is mounted horizontally on top of the roborio.

I start by resetting the gyro in software, and it correctly reports a yaw of 0. I then rotate the robot either CW or CCW for 3 rotations. The reported yaw is off by approx 15 degrees. If I continue in the same direction the error accumulates. When I then rotate in the opposite direction with the same number of rotations, the yaw correctly goes back to 0.

Anyone have an idea of why this is happening?

This sounds like a scaling issue, which we had earlier this season. Here’s a walk through of how to fix that https://www.kauailabs.com/support/navx-mxp/kb/faq.php?id=69 (It’s under the “Gyroscope Scale Factor Ratio” section)

Thanks for the replies.

I replaced the navX2-MXP with a brand new one, and still had the same problem. I then used a navX-MXP and the problem went away.

I’ll  try working with scaling of the navX2-MXP, but at least in the meantime I have a correctly working gyro.

Thanks again for your help.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
In our experience, the scaling function of the NavX2 has been broken since release, and the firmware updates didn’t seem to fix it (particularly if you use it in different orientations).

What we do is we use a scaleFactor that is determined empirically for each NavX2 and we label each one with the factor in case we have to replace them:

Note that if you calibrate the gyro in a different orientation (e.g. vertically or upside down), this scale factor will be different.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: My team is having the same problem, how do you get the scale factor constant?

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
Tom_Neu:

how do you get the scale factor constant?

Start by setting scaleFactor to zero.

Method 1, if your robot is capable of heading hold: Enable the robot and zero the gyro, then tell it to spin in place exactly 10 times (3600 degrees) and measure how far it’s off. For example, if it was short by 45 degrees, then it only turned 3600-45 = 3555 degrees but thought it turned 3600.  So scaleFactor = 3555/3600 = 0.9875

Method 1, if your robot is capable of heading hold: Enable the robot and zero the gyro, then tell it to spin in place exactly 10 times (3600 degrees) and measure how far it’s off. For example, if it was short by 45 degrees, then it only turned 3600-45 = 3555 degrees but thought it turned 3600.  So scaleFactor = 3555/3600 = 0.9875

Method 2, this is more physical labour but only requires the gyro itself: Zero the gyro and manually spin it in place 10 times, and read how far off the gyro position is. For example if it says 45 degrees (and it should read zero), then scaleFactor = 3600/3645 = 0.9877

Method 2, this is more physical labour but only requires the gyro itself: Zero the gyro and manually spin it in place 10 times, and read how far off the gyro position is. For example if it says 45 degrees (and it should read zero), then scaleFactor = 3600/3645 = 0.9877

Then set scaleFactor, do the experiment again, and it should read zero.  If it doesn’t you can tweak it slightly to get the right reading.

Just FYI, it’s common for our NavX2 gyros to be off by up to 10%.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
This is more or less how we did it.  We used just a Robrio on a lazy susan and turned it EXACTLY 10 turns.

BEWARE!

If you do the 10 turn method, there is a scenario where you can calibrate it 36 degrees off.  Yes this actually happened to us which meant the robot would make 2 passes with spins and all the sudden she couldn’t drive it and the gyro would to be 72 degrees in error.
